28/*! \file server/mdb6.c
29 *
30 * \page ipv6structures IPv6 Structures Overview
31 *
32 * A brief description of the IPv6 structures as reverse engineered.
33 *
34 * There are four major data structures in the lease configuraion.
35 *
36 * - shared_network - The shared network is the outer enclosing scope for a
37 * network region that shares a broadcast domain. It is
38 * composed of one or more subnets all of which are valid
39 * in the given region. The share network may be
40 * explicitly defined or implicitly created if there is
41 * only a subnet statement. This structrure is shared
42 * with v4. Each shared network statment or naked subnet
43 * will map to one of these structures
44 *
45 * - subnet - The subnet structure mostly specifies the address range
46 * that could be valid in a given region. This structute
47 * doesn't include the addresses that the server can delegate
48 * those are in the ipv6_pool. This structure is also shared
49 * with v4. Each subnet statement will map to one of these
50 * structures.
51 *
52 * - ipv6_pond - The pond structure is a grouping of the address and prefix
53 * information via the pointers to the ipv6_pool and the
54 * allowability of this pool for given clinets via the permit
55 * lists and the valid TIMEs. This is equivilent to the v4
56 * pool structure and would have been named ip6_pool except
57 * that the name was already in use. Generally each pool6
58 * statement will map to one of these structures. In addition
59 * there may be one or for each group of naked range6 and
60 * prefix6 statements within a shared network that share
61 * the same group of statements.
62 *
63 * - ipv6_pool - this contains information about a pool of addresses or prefixes
64 * that the server is using. This includes a hash table that
65 * tracks the active items and a pair of heap tables one for
66 * active items and one for non-active items. The heap tables
67 * are used to determine the next items to be modified due to
68 * timing events (expire mostly).
69 *
70 * The linkages then look like this:
71 * \verbatim
72 *+--------------+ +-------------+
73 *|Shared Network| | ipv6_pond |
74 *| group | | group |
75 *| | | permit info |
76 *| | | next ---->
77 *| ponds ---->| |
78 *| |<---- shared |
79 *| Subnets | | pools |
80 *+-----|--------+ +------|------+
81 * | ^ | ^
82 * | | v |
83 * | | +-----------|-+
84 * | | | ipv6_pool | |
85 * | | | type | |
86 * | | | ipv6_pond |
87 * | | | |
88 * | | | next ---->
89 * | | | |
90 * | | | subnet |
91 * | | +-----|-------+
92 * | | |
93 * | | v
94 * | | +-------------+
95 * | | | subnet |
96 * | +---------- shared |
97 * +----------->| |
98 * | group |
99 * +-------------+
100 *
101 * The shared network contains a list of all the subnets that are on a broadcast
102 * doamin. These can be used to determine if an address makes sense in a given
103 * domain, but the subnets do not contain the addresses the server can delegate.
104 * Those are stored in the ponds and pools.
105 *
106 * In the simple case to find an acceptable address the server would first find
107 * the shared network the client is on based on either the interface used to
108 * receive the request or the relay agent's information. From the shared
109 * network the server will walk through it's list of ponds. For each pond it
110 * will evaluate the permit information against the (already done) classification.
111 * If it finds an acceptable pond it will then walk through the pools for that
112 * pond. The server first checks the type of the pool (NA, TA and PD) agaisnt the
113 * request and if they match it attemps to find an address within that pool. On
114 * success the address is used, on failure the server steps to the next pool and
115 * if necessary to the next pond.
116 *
117 * When the server is successful in finding an address it will execute any
118 * statements assocaited with the pond, then the subnet, then the shared
119 * network the group field is for in the above picture).
120 *
121 * In configurations that don't include either a shared network or a pool6
122 * statement (or both) the missing pieces are created.
123 *
124 *
125 * There are three major data structuress involved in the lease database:
126 *
127 * - ipv6_pool - see above
128 * - ia_xx - this contains information about a single IA from a request
129 * normally it will contain one pointer to a lease for the client
130 * but it may contain more in some circumstances. There are 3
131 * hash tables to aid in accessing these one each for NA, TA and PD.
132 * - iasubopt - the v6 lease structure. These are created dynamically when
133 * a client asks for something and will eventually be destroyed
134 * if the client doesn't re-ask for that item. A lease has space
135 * for backpointers to the IA and to the pool to which it belongs.
136 * The pool backpointer is always filled, the IA pointer may not be.
137 *
138 * In normal use we then have something like this:
139 *
140 * \verbatim
141 * ia hash tables
142 * ia_na_active +----------------+
143 * ia_ta_active +------------+ | pool |
144 * ia_pd_active | iasubopt |<--| active hash |
145 * +-----------------+ | aka lease |<--| active heap |
146 * | ia_xx | | pool ptr |-->| |
147 * | iasubopt array |<---| iaptr |<--| inactive heap |
148 * | lease ptr |--->| | | |
149 * +-----------------+ +------------+ +----------------+
150 * \endverbatim
151 *
152 * For the pool either the inactive heap will have a pointer
153 * or both the active heap and the active hash will have pointers.
154 *
155 * I think there are several major items to notice. The first is
156 * that as a lease moves around it will be added to and removed
157 * from the address hash table in the pool and between the active
158 * and inactive hash tables. The hash table and the active heap
159 * are used when the lease is either active or abandoned. The
160 * inactive heap is used for all other states. In particular a
161 * lease that has expired or been released will be cleaned
162 * (DDNS removal etc) and then moved to the inactive heap. After
163 * some time period (currently 1 hour) it will be freed.
164 *
165 * The second is that when a client requests specific addresses,
166 * either because it previously owned them or if the server supplied
167 * them as part of a solicit, the server will try to lookup the ia_xx
168 * associated with the client and find the addresses there. If it
169 * does find appropriate leases it moves them from the old IA to
170 * a new IA and eventually replaces the old IA with the new IA
171 * in the IA hash tables.
172 *
173 */
174#include "config.h"

176#include <sys/types.h>
177#include <time.h>
178#include <netinet/in.h>

180#include <stdarg.h>
181#include "dhcpd.h"

183#include "omapip/hash.h"
184#include <isc/md.h>

186HASH_FUNCTIONS(ia, unsigned char *, struct ia_xx, ia_hash_t,
187 ia_reference, ia_dereference, do_string_hash)
188
189ia_hash_t *ia_na_active;
190ia_hash_t *ia_ta_active;
191ia_hash_t *ia_pd_active;
192
193HASH_FUNCTIONS(iasubopt, struct in6_addr *, struct iasubopt, iasubopt_hash_t,
194 iasubopt_reference, iasubopt_dereference, do_string_hash)
195
196struct ipv6_pool **pools;
197int num_pools;
198
199/*
200 * Create a new IAADDR/PREFIX structure.
201 *
202 * - iasubopt must be a pointer to a (struct iasubopt *) pointer previously
203 * initialized to NULL
204 */
205isc_result_t
206iasubopt_allocate(struct iasubopt **iasubopt, const char *file, int line) {
207 struct iasubopt *tmp;
208
209 if (iasubopt == NULL) {
210 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
211 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
212 }
213 if (*iasubopt != NULL) {
214 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
215 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
216 }
217
218 tmp = dmalloc(sizeof(*tmp), file, line);
219 if (tmp == NULL) {
220 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
221 }
222
223 tmp->refcnt = 1;
224 tmp->state = FTS_FREE;
225 tmp->active_index = 0;
226 tmp->inactive_index = 0;
227 tmp->plen = 255;
228
229 *iasubopt = tmp;
230 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
231}
232
233/*
234 * Reference an IAADDR/PREFIX structure.
235 *
236 * - iasubopt must be a pointer to a (struct iasubopt *) pointer previously
237 * initialized to NULL
238 */
239isc_result_t
240iasubopt_reference(struct iasubopt **iasubopt, struct iasubopt *src,
241 const char *file, int line) {
242 if (iasubopt == NULL) {
243 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
244 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
245 }
246 if (*iasubopt != NULL) {
247 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
248 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
249 }
250 if (src == NULL) {
251 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
252 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
253 }
254 *iasubopt = src;
255 src->refcnt++;
256 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
257}
258
259
260/*
261 * Dereference an IAADDR/PREFIX structure.
262 *
263 * If it is the last reference, then the memory for the
264 * structure is freed.
265 */
266isc_result_t
267iasubopt_dereference(struct iasubopt **iasubopt, const char *file, int line) {
268 struct iasubopt *tmp;
269
270 if ((iasubopt == NULL) || (*iasubopt == NULL)) {
271 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer", file, line);
272 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
273 }
274
275 tmp = *iasubopt;
276 *iasubopt = NULL;
277
278 tmp->refcnt--;
279 if (tmp->refcnt < 0) {
280 log_error("%s(%d): negative refcnt", file, line);
281 tmp->refcnt = 0;
282 }
283 if (tmp->refcnt == 0) {
284 if (tmp->ia != NULL) {
285 ia_dereference(&(tmp->ia), file, line);
286 }
287 if (tmp->ipv6_pool != NULL) {
288 ipv6_pool_dereference(&(tmp->ipv6_pool), file, line);
289 }
290 if (tmp->scope != NULL) {
291 binding_scope_dereference(&tmp->scope, file, line);
292 }
293
294 if (tmp->on_star.on_expiry != NULL) {
295 executable_statement_dereference
296 (&tmp->on_star.on_expiry, MDL);
297 }
298 if (tmp->on_star.on_commit != NULL) {
299 executable_statement_dereference
300 (&tmp->on_star.on_commit, MDL);
301 }
302 if (tmp->on_star.on_release != NULL) {
303 executable_statement_dereference
304 (&tmp->on_star.on_release, MDL);
305 }
306
307 dfree(tmp, file, line);
308 }
309
310 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
311}
312
313/*
314 * Make the key that we use for IA.
315 */
316isc_result_t
317ia_make_key(struct data_string *key, u_int32_t iaid,
318 const char *duid, unsigned int duid_len,
319 const char *file, int line) {
320
321 memset(key, 0, sizeof(*key));
322 key->len = duid_len + sizeof(iaid);
323 if (!buffer_allocate(&(key->buffer), key->len, file, line)) {
324 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
325 }
326 key->data = key->buffer->data;
327 memcpy((char *)key->data, &iaid, sizeof(iaid));
328 memcpy((char *)key->data + sizeof(iaid), duid, duid_len);
329
330 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
331}
332
333/*
334 * Create a new IA structure.
335 *
336 * - ia must be a pointer to a (struct ia_xx *) pointer previously
337 * initialized to NULL
338 * - iaid and duid are values from the client
339 *
340 * XXXsk: we don't concern ourself with the byte order of the IAID,
341 * which might be a problem if we transfer this structure
342 * between machines of different byte order
343 */
344isc_result_t
345ia_allocate(struct ia_xx **ia, u_int32_t iaid,
346 const char *duid, unsigned int duid_len,
347 const char *file, int line) {
348 struct ia_xx *tmp;
349
350 if (ia == NULL) {
351 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
352 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
353 }
354 if (*ia != NULL) {
355 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
356 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
357 }
358
359 tmp = dmalloc(sizeof(*tmp), file, line);
360 if (tmp == NULL) {
361 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
362 }
363
364 if (ia_make_key(&tmp->iaid_duid, iaid,
365 duid, duid_len, file, line) != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
366 dfree(tmp, file, line);
367 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
368 }
369
370 tmp->refcnt = 1;
371
372 *ia = tmp;
373 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
374}
375
376/*
377 * Reference an IA structure.
378 *
379 * - ia must be a pointer to a (struct ia_xx *) pointer previously
380 * initialized to NULL
381 */
382isc_result_t
383ia_reference(struct ia_xx **ia, struct ia_xx *src,
384 const char *file, int line) {
385 if (ia == NULL) {
386 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
387 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
388 }
389 if (*ia != NULL) {
390 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
391 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
392 }
393 if (src == NULL) {
394 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
395 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
396 }
397 *ia = src;
398 src->refcnt++;
399 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
400}
401
402/*
403 * Dereference an IA structure.
404 *
405 * If it is the last reference, then the memory for the
406 * structure is freed.
407 */
408isc_result_t
409ia_dereference(struct ia_xx **ia, const char *file, int line) {
410 struct ia_xx *tmp;
411 int i;
412
413 if ((ia == NULL) || (*ia == NULL)) {
414 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer", file, line);
415 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
416 }
417
418 tmp = *ia;
419 *ia = NULL;
420
421 tmp->refcnt--;
422 if (tmp->refcnt < 0) {
423 log_error("%s(%d): negative refcnt", file, line);
424 tmp->refcnt = 0;
425 }
426 if (tmp->refcnt == 0) {
427 if (tmp->iasubopt != NULL) {
428 for (i=0; i<tmp->num_iasubopt; i++) {
429 iasubopt_dereference(&(tmp->iasubopt[i]),
430 file, line);
431 }
432 dfree(tmp->iasubopt, file, line);
433 }
434 data_string_forget(&(tmp->iaid_duid), file, line);
435 dfree(tmp, file, line);
436 }
437 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
438}
439
440
441/*
442 * Add an IAADDR/PREFIX entry to an IA structure.
443 */
444isc_result_t
445ia_add_iasubopt(struct ia_xx *ia, struct iasubopt *iasubopt,
446 const char *file, int line) {
447 int max;
448 struct iasubopt **new;
449
450 /*
451 * Grow our array if we need to.
452 *
453 * Note: we pick 4 as the increment, as that seems a reasonable
454 * guess as to how many addresses/prefixes we might expect
455 * on an interface.
456 */
457 if (ia->max_iasubopt <= ia->num_iasubopt) {
458 max = ia->max_iasubopt + 4;
459 new = dmalloc(max * sizeof(struct iasubopt *), file, line);
460 if (new == NULL) {
461 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
462 }
463 memcpy(new, ia->iasubopt,
464 ia->num_iasubopt * sizeof(struct iasubopt *));
465 ia->iasubopt = new;
466 ia->max_iasubopt = max;
467 }
468
469 iasubopt_reference(&(ia->iasubopt[ia->num_iasubopt]), iasubopt,
470 file, line);
471 ia->num_iasubopt++;
472
473 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
474}
475
476/*
477 * Remove an IAADDR/PREFIX entry to an IA structure.
478 *
479 * Note: if a suboption appears more than once, then only ONE will be removed.
480 */
481void
482ia_remove_iasubopt(struct ia_xx *ia, struct iasubopt *iasubopt,
483 const char *file, int line) {
484 int i, j;
485 if (ia == NULL || iasubopt == NULL)
486 return;
487
488 for (i=0; i<ia->num_iasubopt; i++) {
489 if (ia->iasubopt[i] == iasubopt) {
490 /* remove this sub option */
491 iasubopt_dereference(&(ia->iasubopt[i]), file, line);
492 /* move remaining suboption pointers down one */
493 for (j=i+1; j < ia->num_iasubopt; j++) {
494 ia->iasubopt[j-1] = ia->iasubopt[j];
495 }
496 /* decrease our total count */
497 /* remove the back-reference in the suboption itself */
498 ia_dereference(&iasubopt->ia, file, line);
499 ia->num_iasubopt--;
500 return;
501 }
502 }
503 log_error("%s(%d): IAADDR/PREFIX not in IA", file, line);
504}
505
506/*
507 * Remove all addresses/prefixes from an IA.
508 */
509void
510ia_remove_all_lease(struct ia_xx *ia, const char *file, int line) {
511 int i;
512
513 for (i=0; i<ia->num_iasubopt; i++) {
514 ia_dereference(&(ia->iasubopt[i]->ia), file, line);
515 iasubopt_dereference(&(ia->iasubopt[i]), file, line);
516 }
517 ia->num_iasubopt = 0;
518}
519
520/*
521 * Compare two IA.
522 */
523isc_boolean_t
524ia_equal(const struct ia_xx *a, const struct ia_xx *b)
525{
526 isc_boolean_t found;
527 int i, j;
528
529 /*
530 * Handle cases where one or both of the inputs is NULL.
531 */
532 if (a == NULL) {
533 if (b == NULL) {
534 return ISC_TRUE;
535 } else {
536 return ISC_FALSE;
537 }
538 }
539
540 /*
541 * Check the type is the same.
542 */
543 if (a->ia_type != b->ia_type) {
544 return ISC_FALSE;
545 }
546
547 /*
548 * Check the DUID is the same.
549 */
550 if (a->iaid_duid.len != b->iaid_duid.len) {
551 return ISC_FALSE;
552 }
553 if (memcmp(a->iaid_duid.data,
554 b->iaid_duid.data, a->iaid_duid.len) != 0) {
555 return ISC_FALSE;
556 }
557
558 /*
559 * Make sure we have the same number of addresses/prefixes in each.
560 */
561 if (a->num_iasubopt != b->num_iasubopt) {
562 return ISC_FALSE;
563 }
564
565 /*
566 * Check that each address/prefix is present in both.
567 */
568 for (i=0; i<a->num_iasubopt; i++) {
569 found = ISC_FALSE;
570 for (j=0; j<a->num_iasubopt; j++) {
571 if (a->iasubopt[i]->plen != b->iasubopt[i]->plen)
572 continue;
573 if (memcmp(&(a->iasubopt[i]->addr),
574 &(b->iasubopt[j]->addr),
575 sizeof(struct in6_addr)) == 0) {
576 found = ISC_TRUE;
577 break;
578 }
579 }
580 if (!found) {
581 return ISC_FALSE;
582 }
583 }
584
585 /*
586 * These are the same in every way we care about.
587 */
588 return ISC_TRUE;
589}
590
591/*
592 * Helper function for lease heaps.
593 * Makes the top of the heap the oldest lease.
594 */
595static isc_boolean_t
596lease_older(void *a, void *b) {
597 struct iasubopt *la = (struct iasubopt *)a;
598 struct iasubopt *lb = (struct iasubopt *)b;
599
600 if (la->hard_lifetime_end_time == lb->hard_lifetime_end_time) {
601 return difftime(la->soft_lifetime_end_time,
602 lb->soft_lifetime_end_time) < 0;
603 } else {
604 return difftime(la->hard_lifetime_end_time,
605 lb->hard_lifetime_end_time) < 0;
606 }
607}
608
609/*
610 * Helper functions for lease address/prefix heaps.
611 * Callback when an address's position in the heap changes.
612 */
613static void
614active_changed(void *iasubopt, unsigned int new_heap_index) {
615 ((struct iasubopt *)iasubopt)->active_index = new_heap_index;
616}
617
618static void
619inactive_changed(void *iasubopt, unsigned int new_heap_index) {
620 ((struct iasubopt *)iasubopt)->inactive_index = new_heap_index;
621}
622
623/*!
624 *
625 * \brief Create a new IPv6 lease pool structure
626 *
627 * Allocate space for a new ipv6_pool structure and return a reference
628 * to it, includes setting the reference count to 1.
629 *
630 * \param pool = space for returning a referenced pointer to the pool.
631 * This must point to a space that has been initialzied
632 * to NULL by the caller.
633 * \param[in] type = The type of the pool NA, TA or PD
634 * \param[in] start_addr = The first address in the range for the pool
635 * \param[in] bits = The contiguous bits of the pool
636
637 *
638 * \return
639 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = The pool was successfully created, pool points to it.
640 * DHCP_R_INVALIDARG = One of the arugments was invalid, pool has not been
641 * modified
642 * ISC_R_NOMEMORY = The system wasn't able to allocate memory, pool has
643 * not been modified.
644 */
645isc_result_t
646ipv6_pool_allocate(struct ipv6_pool **pool, u_int16_t type,
647 const struct in6_addr *start_addr, int bits,
648 int units, const char *file, int line) {
649 struct ipv6_pool *tmp;
650
651 if (pool == NULL) {
652 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
653 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
654 }
655 if (*pool != NULL) {
656 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
657 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
658 }
659
660 tmp = dmalloc(sizeof(*tmp), file, line);
661 if (tmp == NULL) {
662 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
663 }
664
665 tmp->refcnt = 1;
666 tmp->pool_type = type;
667 tmp->start_addr = *start_addr;
668 tmp->bits = bits;
669 tmp->units = units;
670 if (!iasubopt_new_hash(&tmp->leases, DEFAULT_HASH_SIZE, file, line)) {
671 dfree(tmp, file, line);
672 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
673 }
674 if (isc_heap_create(dhcp_gbl_ctx.mctx, lease_older, active_changed,
675 0, &(tmp->active_timeouts)) != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
676 iasubopt_free_hash_table(&(tmp->leases), file, line);
677 dfree(tmp, file, line);
678 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
679 }
680 if (isc_heap_create(dhcp_gbl_ctx.mctx, lease_older, inactive_changed,
681 0, &(tmp->inactive_timeouts)) != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
682 isc_heap_destroy(&(tmp->active_timeouts));
683 iasubopt_free_hash_table(&(tmp->leases), file, line);
684 dfree(tmp, file, line);
685 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
686 }
687
688 *pool = tmp;
689 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
690}
691
692/*!
693 *
694 * \brief reference an IPv6 pool structure.
695 *
696 * This function genreates a reference to an ipv6_pool structure
697 * and increments the reference count on the structure.
698 *
699 * \param[out] pool = space for returning a referenced pointer to the pool.
700 * This must point to a space that has been initialzied
701 * to NULL by the caller.
702 * \param[in] src = A pointer to the pool to reference. This must not be
703 * NULL.
704 *
705 * \return
706 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = The pool was successfully referenced, pool now points
707 * to src.
708 * DHCP_R_INVALIDARG = One of the arugments was invalid, pool has not been
709 * modified.
710 */
711isc_result_t
712ipv6_pool_reference(struct ipv6_pool **pool, struct ipv6_pool *src,
713 const char *file, int line) {
714 if (pool == NULL) {
715 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
716 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
717 }
718 if (*pool != NULL) {
719 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
720 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
721 }
722 if (src == NULL) {
723 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
724 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
725 }
726 *pool = src;
727 src->refcnt++;
728 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
729}
730
731/*
732 * Note: Each IAADDR/PREFIX in a pool is referenced by the pool. This is needed
733 * to prevent the lease from being garbage collected out from under the
734 * pool.
735 *
736 * The references are made from the hash and from the heap. The following
737 * helper functions dereference these when a pool is destroyed.
738 */
739
740/*
741 * Helper function for pool cleanup.
742 * Dereference each of the hash entries in a pool.
743 */
744static isc_result_t
745dereference_hash_entry(const void *name, unsigned len, void *value) {
746 struct iasubopt *iasubopt = (struct iasubopt *)value;
747
748 iasubopt_dereference(&iasubopt, MDL);
749 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
750}
751
752/*
753 * Helper function for pool cleanup.
754 * Dereference each of the heap entries in a pool.
755 */
756static void
757dereference_heap_entry(void *value, void *dummy) {
758 struct iasubopt *iasubopt = (struct iasubopt *)value;
759
760 iasubopt_dereference(&iasubopt, MDL);
761}
762
763/*!
764 *
765 * \brief de-reference an IPv6 pool structure.
766 *
767 * This function decrements the reference count in an ipv6_pool structure.
768 * If this was the last reference then the memory for the structure is
769 * freed.
770 *
771 * \param[in] pool = A pointer to the pointer to the pool that should be
772 * de-referenced. On success the pointer to the pool
773 * is cleared. It must not be NULL and must not point
774 * to NULL.
775 *
776 * \return
777 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = The pool was successfully de-referenced, pool now points
778 * to NULL
779 * DHCP_R_INVALIDARG = One of the arugments was invalid, pool has not been
780 * modified.
781 */
782isc_result_t
783ipv6_pool_dereference(struct ipv6_pool **pool, const char *file, int line) {
784 struct ipv6_pool *tmp;
785
786 if ((pool == NULL) || (*pool == NULL)) {
787 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer", file, line);
788 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
789 }
790
791 tmp = *pool;
792 *pool = NULL;
793
794 tmp->refcnt--;
795 if (tmp->refcnt < 0) {
796 log_error("%s(%d): negative refcnt", file, line);
797 tmp->refcnt = 0;
798 }
799 if (tmp->refcnt == 0) {
800 iasubopt_hash_foreach(tmp->leases, dereference_hash_entry);
801 iasubopt_free_hash_table(&(tmp->leases), file, line);
802 isc_heap_foreach(tmp->active_timeouts,
803 dereference_heap_entry, NULL);
804 isc_heap_destroy(&(tmp->active_timeouts));
805 isc_heap_foreach(tmp->inactive_timeouts,
806 dereference_heap_entry, NULL);
807 isc_heap_destroy(&(tmp->inactive_timeouts));
808 dfree(tmp, file, line);
809 }
810
811 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
812}
813
814/*
815 * Create an address by hashing the input, and using that for
816 * the non-network part.
817 */
818static void
819build_address6(struct in6_addr *addr,
820 const struct in6_addr *net_start_addr, int net_bits,
821 const struct data_string *input) {
822 int net_bytes;
823 int i;
824 unsigned int len;
825 char *str;
826 const char *net_str;
827
828 isc_md(ISC_MD_MD5, input->data, input->len, (void *)addr, &len);
829
830 /*
831 * Copy the [0..128] network bits over.
832 */
833 str = (char *)addr;
834 net_str = (const char *)net_start_addr;
835 net_bytes = net_bits / 8;
836 for (i = 0; i < net_bytes; i++) {
837 str[i] = net_str[i];
838 }
839 switch (net_bits % 8) {
840 case 1: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x7F) | (net_str[i] & 0x80); break;
841 case 2: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x3F) | (net_str[i] & 0xC0); break;
842 case 3: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x1F) | (net_str[i] & 0xE0); break;
843 case 4: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x0F) | (net_str[i] & 0xF0); break;
844 case 5: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x07) | (net_str[i] & 0xF8); break;
845 case 6: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x03) | (net_str[i] & 0xFC); break;
846 case 7: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x01) | (net_str[i] & 0xFE); break;
847 }
848
849 /*
850 * Set the universal/local bit ("u bit") to zero for /64s. The
851 * individual/group bit ("g bit") is unchanged, because the g-bit
852 * has no meaning when the u-bit is cleared.
853 */
854 if (net_bits == 64)
855 str[8] &= ~0x02;
856}
857
858#ifdef EUI_64
859int
860valid_eui_64_duid(const struct data_string* uid, int offset) {
861 if (uid->len == (offset + EUI_64_ID_LEN)) {
862 const unsigned char* duid = uid->data + offset;
863 return (((duid[0] == 0x00 && duid[1] == 0x03) &&
864 (duid[2] == 0x00 && duid[3] == 0x1b)));
865 }
866
867 return(0);
868}
869
870
871/*
872 * Create an EUI-64 address
873 */
874static isc_result_t
875build_address6_eui_64(struct in6_addr *addr,
876 const struct in6_addr *net_start_addr, int net_bits,
877 const struct data_string *iaid_duid, int duid_beg) {
878
879 if (net_bits != 64) {
880 log_error("build_address_eui_64: network is not 64 bits");
881 return (ISC_R_FAILURE);
882 }
883
884 if (valid_eui_64_duid(iaid_duid, duid_beg)) {
885 const unsigned char *duid = iaid_duid->data + duid_beg;
886
887 /* copy network prefix to the high 64 bits */
888 memcpy(addr->s6_addr, net_start_addr->s6_addr, 8);
889
890 /* copy Link-layer address to low 64 bits */
891 memcpy(addr->s6_addr + 8, duid + 4, 8);
892
893 /* RFC-3315 Any address assigned by a server that is based
894 * on an EUI-64 identifier MUST include an interface identifier
895 * with the "u" (universal/local) and "g" (individual/group)
896 * bits of the interface identifier set appropriately, as
897 * indicated in section 2.5.1 of RFC 2373 [5]. */
898 addr->s6_addr[8] |= 0x02;
899 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
900 }
901
902 log_error("build_address_eui_64: iaid_duid not a valid EUI-64: %s",
903 print_hex_1(iaid_duid->len, iaid_duid->data, 60));
904 return (ISC_R_FAILURE);
905}
906
907int
908valid_for_eui_64_pool(struct ipv6_pool* pool, struct data_string* uid,
909 int duid_beg, struct in6_addr* ia_addr) {
910 struct in6_addr test_addr;
911 /* If it's not an EUI-64 pool bail */
912 if (!pool->ipv6_pond->use_eui_64) {
913 return (0);
914 }
915
916 if (!valid_eui_64_duid(uid, duid_beg)) {
917 /* Dynamic lease in a now eui_64 pond, toss it*/
918 return (0);
919 }
920
921 /* Call build_address6_eui_64() and compare it's result to
922 * this lease and see if they match. */
923 memset (&test_addr, 0, sizeof(test_addr));
924 build_address6_eui_64(&test_addr, &pool->start_addr, pool->bits,
925 uid, duid_beg);
926
927 return (!memcmp(ia_addr, &test_addr, sizeof(test_addr)));
928}
929#endif
930
931
932/*
933 * Create a temporary address by a variant of RFC 4941 algo.
934 * Note: this should not be used for prefixes shorter than 64 bits.
935 */
936static void
937build_temporary6(struct in6_addr *addr,
938 const struct in6_addr *net_start_addr, int net_bits,
939 const struct data_string *input) {
940 static u_int32_t history[2];
941 static u_int32_t counter = 0;
942 unsigned char md[16] = {0};
943 unsigned int len;
944
945 /*
946 * First time/time to reseed.
947 * Please use a good pseudo-random generator here!
948 */
949 if (counter == 0) {
950 history[0] = arc4random();
951 history[1] = arc4random();
952 }
953
954 /*
955 * Use MD5 as recommended by RFC 4941.
956 */
957 isc_md(ISC_MD_MD5, input->data, input->len, (void *)&history[0], &len);
958
959 /*
960 * Build the address.
961 */
962 if (net_bits == 64) {
963 memcpy(&addr->s6_addr[0], &net_start_addr->s6_addr[0], 8);
964 memcpy(&addr->s6_addr[8], md, 8);
965 addr->s6_addr[8] &= ~0x02;
966 } else {
967 int net_bytes;
968 int i;
969 char *str;
970 const char *net_str;
971
972 /*
973 * Copy the [0..128] network bits over.
974 */
975 str = (char *)addr;
976 net_str = (const char *)net_start_addr;
977 net_bytes = net_bits / 8;
978 for (i = 0; i < net_bytes; i++) {
979 str[i] = net_str[i];
980 }
981 memcpy(str + net_bytes, md, 16 - net_bytes);
982 switch (net_bits % 8) {
983 case 1: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x7F) | (net_str[i] & 0x80); break;
984 case 2: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x3F) | (net_str[i] & 0xC0); break;
985 case 3: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x1F) | (net_str[i] & 0xE0); break;
986 case 4: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x0F) | (net_str[i] & 0xF0); break;
987 case 5: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x07) | (net_str[i] & 0xF8); break;
988 case 6: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x03) | (net_str[i] & 0xFC); break;
989 case 7: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x01) | (net_str[i] & 0xFE); break;
990 }
991 }
992
993
994 /*
995 * Save history for the next call.
996 */
997 memcpy((unsigned char *)&history[0], md + 8, 8);
998 counter++;
999}
1000
1001/* Reserved Subnet Router Anycast ::0:0:0:0. */
1002static struct in6_addr rtany;
1003/* Reserved Subnet Anycasts ::fdff:ffff:ffff:ff80-::fdff:ffff:ffff:ffff. */
1004static struct in6_addr resany;
1005
1006/*
1007 * Create a lease for the given address and client duid.
1008 *
1009 * - pool must be a pointer to a (struct ipv6_pool *) pointer previously
1010 * initialized to NULL
1011 *
1012 * Right now we simply hash the DUID, and if we get a collision, we hash
1013 * again until we find a free address. We try this a fixed number of times,
1014 * to avoid getting stuck in a loop (this is important on small pools
1015 * where we can run out of space).
1016 *
1017 * We return the number of attempts that it took to find an available
1018 * lease. This tells callers when a pool is are filling up, as
1019 * well as an indication of how full the pool is; statistically the
1020 * more full a pool is the more attempts must be made before finding
1021 * a free lease. Realistically this will only happen in very full
1022 * pools.
1023 *
1024 * We probably want different algorithms depending on the network size, in
1025 * the long term.
1026 */
1027isc_result_t
1028create_lease6(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt **addr,
1029 unsigned int *attempts,
1030 const struct data_string *uid, time_t soft_lifetime_end_time) {
1031 struct data_string ds;
1032 struct in6_addr tmp;
1033 struct iasubopt *test_iaaddr;
1034 struct data_string new_ds;
1035 struct iasubopt *iaaddr;
1036 isc_result_t result;
1037 isc_boolean_t reserved_iid;
1038 static isc_boolean_t init_resiid = ISC_FALSE;
1039
1040 /*
1041 * Fill the reserved IIDs.
1042 */
1043 if (!init_resiid) {
1044 memset(&rtany, 0, 16);
1045 memset(&resany, 0, 8);
1046 resany.s6_addr[8] = 0xfd;
1047 memset(&resany.s6_addr[9], 0xff, 6);
1048 init_resiid = ISC_TRUE;
1049 }
1050
1051 /*
1052 * Use the UID as our initial seed for the hash
1053 */
1054 memset(&ds, 0, sizeof(ds));
1055 data_string_copy(&ds, (struct data_string *)uid, MDL);
1056
1057 *attempts = 0;
1058 for (;;) {
1059 /*
1060 * Give up at some point.
1061 */
1062 if (++(*attempts) > 100) {
1063 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1064 return ISC_R_NORESOURCES;
1065 }
1066
1067 /*
1068 * Build a resource.
1069 */
1070 switch (pool->pool_type) {
1071 case D6O_IA_NA:
1072 /* address */
1073 build_address6(&tmp, &pool->start_addr,
1074 pool->bits, &ds);
1075 break;
1076 case D6O_IA_TA:
1077 /* temporary address */
1078 build_temporary6(&tmp, &pool->start_addr,
1079 pool->bits, &ds);
1080 break;
1081 case D6O_IA_PD:
1082 /* prefix */
1083 log_error("create_lease6: prefix pool.");
1084 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
1085 default:
1086 log_error("create_lease6: untyped pool.");
1087 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
1088 }
1089
1090 /*
1091 * Avoid reserved interface IDs. (cf. RFC 5453)
1092 */
1093 reserved_iid = ISC_FALSE;
1094 if (memcmp(&tmp.s6_addr[8], &rtany.s6_addr[8], 8) == 0) {
1095 reserved_iid = ISC_TRUE;
1096 }
1097 if (!reserved_iid &&
1098 (memcmp(&tmp.s6_addr[8], &resany.s6_addr[8], 7) == 0) &&
1099 ((tmp.s6_addr[15] & 0x80) == 0x80)) {
1100 reserved_iid = ISC_TRUE;
1101 }
1102
1103 /*
1104 * If this address is not in use, we're happy with it
1105 */
1106 test_iaaddr = NULL;
1107 if (!reserved_iid &&
1108 (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iaaddr, pool->leases,
1109 &tmp, sizeof(tmp), MDL) == 0)) {
1110 break;
1111 }
1112 if (test_iaaddr != NULL)
1113 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iaaddr, MDL);
1114
1115 /*
1116 * Otherwise, we create a new input, adding the address
1117 */
1118 memset(&new_ds, 0, sizeof(new_ds));
1119 new_ds.len = ds.len + sizeof(tmp);
1120 if (!buffer_allocate(&new_ds.buffer, new_ds.len, MDL)) {
1121 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1122 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
1123 }
1124 new_ds.data = new_ds.buffer->data;
1125 memcpy(new_ds.buffer->data, ds.data, ds.len);
1126 memcpy(new_ds.buffer->data + ds.len, &tmp, sizeof(tmp));
1127 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1128 data_string_copy(&ds, &new_ds, MDL);
1129 data_string_forget(&new_ds, MDL);
1130 }
1131
1132 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1133
1134 /*
1135 * We're happy with the address, create an IAADDR
1136 * to hold it.
1137 */
1138 iaaddr = NULL;
1139 result = iasubopt_allocate(&iaaddr, MDL);
1140 if (result != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1141 return result;
1142 }
1143 iaaddr->plen = 0;
1144 memcpy(&iaaddr->addr, &tmp, sizeof(iaaddr->addr));
1145
1146 /*
1147 * Add the lease to the pool (note state is free, not active?!).
1148 */
1149 result = add_lease6(pool, iaaddr, soft_lifetime_end_time);
1150 if (result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1151 iasubopt_reference(addr, iaaddr, MDL);
1152 }
1153 iasubopt_dereference(&iaaddr, MDL);
1154 return result;
1155}
1156
1157#ifdef EUI_64
1158/*!
1159 * \brief Assign an EUI-64 address from a pool for a given iaid-duid
1160 *
1161 * \param pool - pool from which the address is assigned
1162 * \param iaddr - pointer to the iasubopt to contain the assigned address is
1163 * \param uid - data_string containing the iaid-duid tuple
1164 * \param soft_lifetime_end_time - lifetime of the lease for a solicit?
1165 *
1166 * \return status indicating success or nature of the failure
1167*/
1168isc_result_t
1169create_lease6_eui_64(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt **addr,
1170 const struct data_string *uid,
1171 time_t soft_lifetime_end_time) {
1172 struct in6_addr tmp;
1173 struct iasubopt *test_iaaddr;
1174 struct iasubopt *iaaddr;
1175 isc_result_t result;
1176 static isc_boolean_t init_resiid = ISC_FALSE;
1177
1178 /* Fill the reserved IIDs. */
1179 if (!init_resiid) {
1180 memset(&rtany, 0, 16);
1181 memset(&resany, 0, 8);
1182 resany.s6_addr[8] = 0xfd;
1183 memset(&resany.s6_addr[9], 0xff, 6);
1184 init_resiid = ISC_TRUE;
1185 }
1186
1187 /* Pool must be IA_NA */
1188 if (pool->pool_type != D6O_IA_NA) {
1189 log_error("create_lease6_eui_64: pool type is not IA_NA.");
1190 return (DHCP_R_INVALIDARG);
1191 }
1192
1193 /* Attempt to build the address */
1194 if (build_address6_eui_64 (&tmp, &pool->start_addr, pool->bits,
1195 uid, IAID_LEN) != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1196 log_error("create_lease6_eui_64: build_address6_eui_64 failed");
1197 return (ISC_R_FAILURE);
1198 }
1199
1200 /* Avoid reserved interface IDs. (cf. RFC 5453) */
1201 if ((memcmp(&tmp.s6_addr[8], &rtany.s6_addr[8], 8) == 0) ||
1202 ((memcmp(&tmp.s6_addr[8], &resany.s6_addr[8], 7) == 0) &&
1203 ((tmp.s6_addr[15] & 0x80) == 0x80))) {
1204 log_error("create_lease6_eui_64: "
1205 "address conflicts with reserved IID");
1206 return (ISC_R_FAILURE);
1207 }
1208
1209 /* If this address is not in use, we're happy with it */
1210 test_iaaddr = NULL;
1211 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iaaddr, pool->leases,
1212 &tmp, sizeof(tmp), MDL) != 0) {
1213
1214 /* See if it's ours. Static leases won't have an ia */
1215 int ours = 0;
1216 if (!test_iaaddr->ia) {
1217 log_error("create_lease6_eui_64: "
1218 "address %s is assigned to static lease",
1219 pin6_addr(&test_iaaddr->addr));
1220 } else {
1221 /* Not sure if this can actually happen */
1222 struct data_string* found = &test_iaaddr->ia->iaid_duid;
1223 ours = ((found->len == uid->len) &&
1224 (!memcmp(found->data, uid->data, uid->len)));
1225 log_error("create_lease6_eui_64: "
1226 "address %s belongs to %s",
1227 pin6_addr(&test_iaaddr->addr),
1228 print_hex_1(found->len, found->data, 60));
1229 }
1230
1231 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iaaddr, MDL);
1232 if (!ours) {
1233 /* Cant' use it */
1234 return (ISC_R_FAILURE);
1235 }
1236 }
1237
1238 /* We're happy with the address, create an IAADDR to hold it. */
1239 iaaddr = NULL;
1240 result = iasubopt_allocate(&iaaddr, MDL);
1241 if (result != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1242 log_error("create_lease6_eui_64: could not allocate iasubop");
1243 return result;
1244 }
1245 iaaddr->plen = 0;
1246 memcpy(&iaaddr->addr, &tmp, sizeof(iaaddr->addr));
1247
1248 /* Add the lease to the pool and the reply */
1249 result = add_lease6(pool, iaaddr, soft_lifetime_end_time);
1250 if (result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1251 iasubopt_reference(addr, iaaddr, MDL);
1252 }
1253
1254 iasubopt_dereference(&iaaddr, MDL);
1255 return result;
1256}
1257#endif
1258
1259/*!
1260 *
1261 * \brief Cleans up leases when reading from a lease file
1262 *
1263 * This function is only expected to be run when reading leases in from a file.
1264 * It checks to see if a lease already exists for the new leases's address.
1265 * We don't add expired leases to the structures when reading a lease file
1266 * which limits what can happen. We have two variables the owners of the leases
1267 * being the same or different and the new lease being active or non-active:
1268 * Owners active
1269 * same no remove old lease and its connections
1270 * same yes nothing to do, other code will update the structures.
1271 * diff no nothing to do
1272 * diff yes this combination shouldn't happen, we should only have a
1273 * single active lease per address at a time and that lease
1274 * should move to non-active before any other lease can
1275 * become active for that address.
1276 * Currently we delete the previous lease and pass an error
1277 * to the caller who should log an error.
1278 *
1279 * When we remove a lease we remove it from the hash table and active heap
1280 * (remember only active leases are in the structures at this time) for the
1281 * pool, and from the IA's array. If, after we've removed the pointer from
1282 * IA's array to the lease, the IA has no more pointers we remove it from
1283 * the appropriate hash table as well.
1284 *
1285 * \param[in] ia_table = the hash table for the IA
1286 * \param[in] pool = the pool to update
1287 * \param[in] lease = the new lease we want to add
1288 * \param[in] ia = the new ia we are building
1289 *
1290 * \return
1291 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = the incoming lease and any previous lease were in
1292 * an expected state - one of the first 3 options above.
1293 * If necessary the old lease was removed.
1294 * ISC_R_FAILURE = there is already an active lease for the address in
1295 * the incoming lease. This shouldn't happen if it does
1296 * flag an error for the caller to log.
1297 */
1298
1299isc_result_t
1300cleanup_lease6(ia_hash_t *ia_table,
1301 struct ipv6_pool *pool,
1302 struct iasubopt *lease,
1303 struct ia_xx *ia) {
1304
1305 struct iasubopt *test_iasubopt, *tmp_iasubopt;
1306 struct ia_xx *old_ia;
1307 isc_result_t status = ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1308
1309 test_iasubopt = NULL;
1310 old_ia = NULL;
1311
1312 /*
1313 * Look up the address - if we don't find a lease
1314 * we don't need to do anything.
1315 */
1316 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iasubopt, pool->leases,
1317 &lease->addr, sizeof(lease->addr),
1318 MDL) == 0) {
1319 return (ISC_R_SUCCESS);
1320 }
1321
1322 if (test_iasubopt->ia == NULL) {
1323 /* no old ia, no work to do */
1324 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iasubopt, MDL);
1325 return (status);
1326 }
1327
1328 ia_reference(&old_ia, test_iasubopt->ia, MDL);
1329
1330 if ((old_ia->iaid_duid.len == ia->iaid_duid.len) &&
1331 (memcmp((unsigned char *)ia->iaid_duid.data,
1332 (unsigned char *)old_ia->iaid_duid.data,
1333 ia->iaid_duid.len) == 0)) {
1334 /* same IA */
1335 if ((lease->state == FTS_ACTIVE) ||
1336 (lease->state == FTS_ABANDONED)) {
1337 /* still active, no need to delete */
1338 goto cleanup;
1339 }
1340 } else {
1341 /* different IA */
1342 if ((lease->state != FTS_ACTIVE) &&
1343 (lease->state != FTS_ABANDONED)) {
1344 /* new lease isn't active, no work */
1345 goto cleanup;
1346 }
1347
1348 /*
1349 * We appear to have two active leases, this shouldn't happen.
1350 * Before a second lease can be set to active the first lease
1351 * should be set to inactive (released, expired etc). For now
1352 * delete the previous lease and indicate a failure to the
1353 * caller so it can generate a warning.
1354 * In the future we may try and determine which is the better
1355 * lease to keep.
1356 */
1357
1358 status = ISC_R_FAILURE;
1359 }
1360
1361 /*
1362 * Remove the old lease from the active heap and from the hash table
1363 * then remove the lease from the IA and clean up the IA if necessary.
1364 */
1365 isc_heap_delete(pool->active_timeouts, test_iasubopt->active_index);
1366 pool->num_active--;
1367 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1368 pool->ipv6_pond->num_active--;
1369
1370 if (lease->state == FTS_ABANDONED) {
1371 pool->num_abandoned--;
1372 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1373 pool->ipv6_pond->num_abandoned--;
1374 }
1375
1376 iasubopt_hash_delete(pool->leases, &test_iasubopt->addr,
1377 sizeof(test_iasubopt->addr), MDL);
1378 ia_remove_iasubopt(old_ia, test_iasubopt, MDL);
1379 if (old_ia->num_iasubopt <= 0) {
1380 ia_hash_delete(ia_table,
1381 (unsigned char *)old_ia->iaid_duid.data,
1382 old_ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL);
1383 }
1384
1385 /*
1386 * We derefenrece the subopt here as we've just removed it from
1387 * the hash table in the pool. We need to make a copy as we
1388 * need to derefernece it again later.
1389 */
1390 tmp_iasubopt = test_iasubopt;
1391 iasubopt_dereference(&tmp_iasubopt, MDL);
1392
1393 cleanup:
1394 ia_dereference(&old_ia, MDL);
1395
1396 /*
1397 * Clean up the reference, this is in addition to the deference
1398 * above after removing the entry from the hash table
1399 */
1400 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iasubopt, MDL);
1401
1402 return (status);
1403}
1404
1405/*
1406 * Put a lease in the pool directly. This is intended to be used when
1407 * loading leases from the file.
1408 */
1409isc_result_t
1410add_lease6(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt *lease,
1411 time_t valid_lifetime_end_time) {
1412 isc_result_t insert_result;
1413 struct iasubopt *test_iasubopt;
1414 struct iasubopt *tmp_iasubopt;
1415
1416 /* If a state was not assigned by the caller, assume active. */
1417 if (lease->state == 0)
1418 lease->state = FTS_ACTIVE;
1419
1420 ipv6_pool_reference(&lease->ipv6_pool, pool, MDL);
1421
1422 /*
1423 * If this IAADDR/PREFIX is already in our structures, remove the
1424 * old one.
1425 */
1426 test_iasubopt = NULL;
1427 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iasubopt, pool->leases,
1428 &lease->addr, sizeof(lease->addr), MDL)) {
1429 /* XXX: we should probably ask the lease what heap it is on
1430 * (as a consistency check).
1431 * XXX: we should probably have one function to "put this lease
1432 * on its heap" rather than doing these if's everywhere. If
1433 * you add more states to this list, don't.
1434 */
1435 if ((test_iasubopt->state == FTS_ACTIVE) ||
1436 (test_iasubopt->state == FTS_ABANDONED)) {
1437 isc_heap_delete(pool->active_timeouts,
1438 test_iasubopt->active_index);
1439 pool->num_active--;
1440 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1441 pool->ipv6_pond->num_active--;
1442
1443 if (test_iasubopt->state == FTS_ABANDONED) {
1444 pool->num_abandoned--;
1445 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1446 pool->ipv6_pond->num_abandoned--;
1447 }
1448 } else {
1449 isc_heap_delete(pool->inactive_timeouts,
1450 test_iasubopt->inactive_index);
1451 pool->num_inactive--;
1452 }
1453
1454 iasubopt_hash_delete(pool->leases, &test_iasubopt->addr,
1455 sizeof(test_iasubopt->addr), MDL);
1456
1457 /*
1458 * We're going to do a bit of evil trickery here.
1459 *
1460 * We need to dereference the entry once to remove our
1461 * current reference (in test_iasubopt), and then one
1462 * more time to remove the reference left when the
1463 * address was added to the pool before.
1464 */
1465 tmp_iasubopt = test_iasubopt;
1466 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iasubopt, MDL);
1467 iasubopt_dereference(&tmp_iasubopt, MDL);
1468 }
1469
1470 /*
1471 * Add IAADDR/PREFIX to our structures.
1472 */
1473 tmp_iasubopt = NULL;
1474 iasubopt_reference(&tmp_iasubopt, lease, MDL);
1475 if ((tmp_iasubopt->state == FTS_ACTIVE) ||
1476 (tmp_iasubopt->state == FTS_ABANDONED)) {
1477 tmp_iasubopt->hard_lifetime_end_time = valid_lifetime_end_time;
1478 iasubopt_hash_add(pool->leases, &tmp_iasubopt->addr,
1479 sizeof(tmp_iasubopt->addr), lease, MDL);
1480 insert_result = isc_heap_insert(pool->active_timeouts,
1481 tmp_iasubopt);
1482 if (insert_result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1483 pool->num_active++;
1484 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1485 pool->ipv6_pond->num_active++;
1486
1487 if (tmp_iasubopt->state == FTS_ABANDONED) {
1488 pool->num_abandoned++;
1489 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1490 pool->ipv6_pond->num_abandoned++;
1491 }
1492 }
1493
1494 } else {
1495 tmp_iasubopt->soft_lifetime_end_time = valid_lifetime_end_time;
1496 insert_result = isc_heap_insert(pool->inactive_timeouts,
1497 tmp_iasubopt);
1498 if (insert_result == ISC_R_SUCCESS)
1499 pool->num_inactive++;
1500 }
1501 if (insert_result != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1502 iasubopt_hash_delete(pool->leases, &lease->addr,
1503 sizeof(lease->addr), MDL);
1504 iasubopt_dereference(&tmp_iasubopt, MDL);
1505 return insert_result;
1506 }
1507
1508 /*
1509 * Note: we intentionally leave tmp_iasubopt referenced; there
1510 * is a reference in the heap/hash, after all.
1511 */
1512
1513 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1514}
1515
1516/*
1517 * Determine if an address is present in a pool or not.
1518 */
1519isc_boolean_t
1520lease6_exists(const struct ipv6_pool *pool, const struct in6_addr *addr) {
1521 struct iasubopt *test_iaaddr;
1522
1523 test_iaaddr = NULL;
1524 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iaaddr, pool->leases,
1525 (void *)addr, sizeof(*addr), MDL)) {
1526 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iaaddr, MDL);
1527 return ISC_TRUE;
1528 } else {
1529 return ISC_FALSE;
1530 }
1531}
1532
1533/*!
1534 *
1535 * \brief Check if address is available to a lease
1536 *
1537 * Determine if the address in the lease is available to that
1538 * lease. Either the address isn't in use or it is in use
1539 * but by that lease.
1540 *
1541 * \param[in] lease = lease to check
1542 *
1543 * \return
1544 * ISC_TRUE = The lease is allowed to use that address
1545 * ISC_FALSE = The lease isn't allowed to use that address
1546 */
1547isc_boolean_t
1548lease6_usable(struct iasubopt *lease) {
1549 struct iasubopt *test_iaaddr;
1550 isc_boolean_t status = ISC_TRUE;
1551
1552 test_iaaddr = NULL;
1553 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iaaddr, lease->ipv6_pool->leases,
1554 (void *)&lease->addr,
1555 sizeof(lease->addr), MDL)) {
1556 if (test_iaaddr != lease) {
1557 status = ISC_FALSE;
1558 }
1559 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iaaddr, MDL);
1560 }
1561
1562 return (status);
1563}
1564
1565/*
1566 * Put the lease on our active pool.
1567 */
1568static isc_result_t
1569move_lease_to_active(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt *lease) {
1570 isc_result_t insert_result;
1571
1572 insert_result = isc_heap_insert(pool->active_timeouts, lease);
1573 if (insert_result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1574 iasubopt_hash_add(pool->leases, &lease->addr,
1575 sizeof(lease->addr), lease, MDL);
1576 isc_heap_delete(pool->inactive_timeouts,
1577 lease->inactive_index);
1578 pool->num_active++;
1579 pool->num_inactive--;
1580 lease->state = FTS_ACTIVE;
1581 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1582 pool->ipv6_pond->num_active++;
1583
1584 }
1585 return insert_result;
1586}
1587
1588/*!
1589 *
1590 * \brief Renew a lease in the pool.
1591 *
1592 * The hard_lifetime_end_time of the lease should be set to
1593 * the current expiration time.
1594 * The soft_lifetime_end_time of the lease should be set to
1595 * the desired expiration time.
1596 *
1597 * This routine will compare the two and call the correct
1598 * heap routine to move the lease. If the lease is active
1599 * and the new expiration time is greater (the normal case)
1600 * then we call isc_heap_decreased() as a larger time is a
1601 * lower priority. If the new expiration time is less then
1602 * we call isc_heap_increased().
1603 *
1604 * If the lease is abandoned then it will be on the active list
1605 * and we will always call isc_heap_increased() as the previous
1606 * expiration would have been all 1s (as close as we can get
1607 * to infinite).
1608 *
1609 * If the lease is moving to active we call that routine
1610 * which will move it from the inactive list to the active list.
1611 *
1612 * \param pool = a pool the lease belongs to
1613 * \param lease = the lease to be renewed
1614 *
1615 * \return result of the renew operation (ISC_R_SUCCESS if successful,
1616 ISC_R_NOMEMORY when run out of memory)
1617 */
1618isc_result_t
1619renew_lease6(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt *lease) {
1620 time_t old_end_time = lease->hard_lifetime_end_time;
1621 lease->hard_lifetime_end_time = lease->soft_lifetime_end_time;
1622 lease->soft_lifetime_end_time = 0;
1623
1624 if (lease->state == FTS_ACTIVE) {
1625 if (old_end_time <= lease->hard_lifetime_end_time) {
1626 isc_heap_decreased(pool->active_timeouts,
1627 lease->active_index);
1628 } else {
1629 isc_heap_increased(pool->active_timeouts,
1630 lease->active_index);
1631 }
1632 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1633 } else if (lease->state == FTS_ABANDONED) {
1634 char tmp_addr[INET6_ADDRSTRLEN];
1635 lease->state = FTS_ACTIVE;
1636 isc_heap_increased(pool->active_timeouts, lease->active_index);
1637 log_info("Reclaiming previously abandoned address %s",
1638 inet_ntop(AF_INET6, &(lease->addr), tmp_addr,
1639 sizeof(tmp_addr)));
1640
1641 pool->num_abandoned--;
1642 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1643 pool->ipv6_pond->num_abandoned--;
1644
1645 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1646 } else {
1647 return move_lease_to_active(pool, lease);
1648 }
1649}
1650
1651/*
1652 * Put the lease on our inactive pool, with the specified state.
1653 */
1654static isc_result_t
1655move_lease_to_inactive(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt *lease,
1656 binding_state_t state) {
1657 isc_result_t insert_result;
1658
1659 insert_result = isc_heap_insert(pool->inactive_timeouts, lease);
1660 if (insert_result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1661 /*
1662 * Handle expire and release statements
1663 * To get here we must be active and have done a commit so
1664 * we should run the proper statements if they exist, though
1665 * that will change when we remove the inactive heap.
1666 * In addition we get rid of the references for both as we
1667 * can only do one (expire or release) on a lease
1668 */
1669 if (lease->on_star.on_expiry != NULL) {
1670 if (state == FTS_EXPIRED) {
1671 execute_statements(NULL, NULL, NULL,
1672 NULL, NULL, NULL,
1673 &lease->scope,
1674 lease->on_star.on_expiry,
1675 &lease->on_star);
1676 }
1677 executable_statement_dereference
1678 (&lease->on_star.on_expiry, MDL);
1679 }
1680
1681 if (lease->on_star.on_release != NULL) {
1682 if (state == FTS_RELEASED) {
1683 execute_statements(NULL, NULL, NULL,
1684 NULL, NULL, NULL,
1685 &lease->scope,
1686 lease->on_star.on_release,
1687 &lease->on_star);
1688 }
1689 executable_statement_dereference
1690 (&lease->on_star.on_release, MDL);
1691 }
1692
1693#if defined (NSUPDATE)
1694 /* Process events upon expiration. */
1695 if (pool->pool_type != D6O_IA_PD) {
1696 (void) ddns_removals(NULL, lease, NULL, ISC_FALSE);
1697 }
1698#endif
1699
1700 /* Binding scopes are no longer valid after expiry or
1701 * release.
1702 */
1703 if (lease->scope != NULL) {
1704 binding_scope_dereference(&lease->scope, MDL);
1705 }
1706
1707 iasubopt_hash_delete(pool->leases,
1708 &lease->addr, sizeof(lease->addr), MDL);
1709 isc_heap_delete(pool->active_timeouts, lease->active_index);
1710 lease->state = state;
1711 pool->num_active--;
1712 pool->num_inactive++;
1713 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1714 pool->ipv6_pond->num_active--;
1715
1716 if (lease->state == FTS_ABANDONED) {
1717 pool->num_abandoned--;
1718 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1719 pool->ipv6_pond->num_abandoned--;
1720 }
1721 }
1722 return insert_result;
1723}
1724
1725/*
1726 * Expire the oldest lease if it's lifetime_end_time is
1727 * older than the given time.
1728 *
1729 * - leasep must be a pointer to a (struct iasubopt *) pointer previously
1730 * initialized to NULL
1731 *
1732 * On return leasep has a reference to the removed entry. It is left
1733 * pointing to NULL if the oldest lease has not expired.
1734 */
1735isc_result_t
1736expire_lease6(struct iasubopt **leasep, struct ipv6_pool *pool, time_t now) {
1737 struct iasubopt *tmp;
1738 isc_result_t result;
1739
1740 if (leasep == NULL) {
1741 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", MDL);
1742 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
1743 }
1744 if (*leasep != NULL) {
1745 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", MDL);
1746 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
1747 }
1748
1749 if (pool->num_active > 0) {
1750 tmp = (struct iasubopt *)
1751 isc_heap_element(pool->active_timeouts, 1);
1752 if (now > tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time) {
1753 result = move_lease_to_inactive(pool, tmp,
1754 FTS_EXPIRED);
1755 if (result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1756 iasubopt_reference(leasep, tmp, MDL);
1757 }
1758 return result;
1759 }
1760 }
1761 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1762}
1763
1764
1765/*
1766 * For a declined lease, leave it on the "active" pool, but mark
1767 * it as declined. Give it an infinite (well, really long) life.
1768 */
1769isc_result_t
1770decline_lease6(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt *lease) {
1771 isc_result_t result;
1772
1773 if ((lease->state != FTS_ACTIVE) &&
1774 (lease->state != FTS_ABANDONED)) {
1775 result = move_lease_to_active(pool, lease);
1776 if (result != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1777 return result;
1778 }
1779 }
1780 lease->state = FTS_ABANDONED;
1781
1782 pool->num_abandoned++;
1783 if (pool->ipv6_pond)
1784 pool->ipv6_pond->num_abandoned++;
1785
1786 lease->hard_lifetime_end_time = MAX_TIME;
1787 isc_heap_decreased(pool->active_timeouts, lease->active_index);
1788 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1789}
1790
1791/*
1792 * Put the returned lease on our inactive pool.
1793 */
1794isc_result_t
1795release_lease6(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt *lease) {
1796 if (lease->state == FTS_ACTIVE) {
1797 return move_lease_to_inactive(pool, lease, FTS_RELEASED);
1798 } else {
1799 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
1800 }
1801}
1802
1803/*
1804 * Create a prefix by hashing the input, and using that for
1805 * the part subject to allocation.
1806 */
1807static void
1808build_prefix6(struct in6_addr *pref,
1809 const struct in6_addr *net_start_pref,
1810 int pool_bits, int pref_bits,
1811 const struct data_string *input) {
1812 int net_bytes;
1813 int i;
1814 unsigned int len;
1815 char *str;
1816 const char *net_str;
1817
1818 /*
1819 * Use MD5 to get a nice 128 bit hash of the input.
1820 * Yes, we know MD5 isn't cryptographically sound.
1821 * No, we don't care.
1822 */
1823 isc_md(ISC_MD_MD5, input->data, input->len, (void *)&pref, &len);
1824
1825 /*
1826 * Copy the network bits over.
1827 */
1828 str = (char *)pref;
1829 net_str = (const char *)net_start_pref;
1830 net_bytes = pool_bits / 8;
1831 for (i = 0; i < net_bytes; i++) {
1832 str[i] = net_str[i];
1833 }
1834 i = net_bytes;
1835 switch (pool_bits % 8) {
1836 case 1: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x7F) | (net_str[i] & 0x80); break;
1837 case 2: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x3F) | (net_str[i] & 0xC0); break;
1838 case 3: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x1F) | (net_str[i] & 0xE0); break;
1839 case 4: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x0F) | (net_str[i] & 0xF0); break;
1840 case 5: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x07) | (net_str[i] & 0xF8); break;
1841 case 6: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x03) | (net_str[i] & 0xFC); break;
1842 case 7: str[i] = (str[i] & 0x01) | (net_str[i] & 0xFE); break;
1843 }
1844 /*
1845 * Zero the remaining bits.
1846 */
1847 net_bytes = pref_bits / 8;
1848 for (i=net_bytes+1; i<16; i++) {
1849 str[i] = 0;
1850 }
1851 i = net_bytes;
1852 switch (pref_bits % 8) {
1853 case 0: str[i] &= 0; break;
1854 case 1: str[i] &= 0x80; break;
1855 case 2: str[i] &= 0xC0; break;
1856 case 3: str[i] &= 0xE0; break;
1857 case 4: str[i] &= 0xF0; break;
1858 case 5: str[i] &= 0xF8; break;
1859 case 6: str[i] &= 0xFC; break;
1860 case 7: str[i] &= 0xFE; break;
1861 }
1862}
1863
1864/*
1865 * Create a lease for the given prefix and client duid.
1866 *
1867 * - pool must be a pointer to a (struct ipv6_pool *) pointer previously
1868 * initialized to NULL
1869 *
1870 * Right now we simply hash the DUID, and if we get a collision, we hash
1871 * again until we find a free prefix. We try this a fixed number of times,
1872 * to avoid getting stuck in a loop (this is important on small pools
1873 * where we can run out of space).
1874 *
1875 * We return the number of attempts that it took to find an available
1876 * prefix. This tells callers when a pool is are filling up, as
1877 * well as an indication of how full the pool is; statistically the
1878 * more full a pool is the more attempts must be made before finding
1879 * a free prefix. Realistically this will only happen in very full
1880 * pools.
1881 *
1882 * We probably want different algorithms depending on the network size, in
1883 * the long term.
1884 */
1885isc_result_t
1886create_prefix6(struct ipv6_pool *pool, struct iasubopt **pref,
1887 unsigned int *attempts,
1888 const struct data_string *uid,
1889 time_t soft_lifetime_end_time) {
1890 struct data_string ds;
1891 struct in6_addr tmp;
1892 struct iasubopt *test_iapref;
1893 struct data_string new_ds;
1894 struct iasubopt *iapref;
1895 isc_result_t result;
1896
1897 /*
1898 * Use the UID as our initial seed for the hash
1899 */
1900 memset(&ds, 0, sizeof(ds));
1901 data_string_copy(&ds, (struct data_string *)uid, MDL);
1902
1903 *attempts = 0;
1904 for (;;) {
1905 /*
1906 * Give up at some point.
1907 */
1908 if (++(*attempts) > 10) {
1909 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1910 return ISC_R_NORESOURCES;
1911 }
1912
1913 /*
1914 * Build a prefix
1915 */
1916 build_prefix6(&tmp, &pool->start_addr,
1917 pool->bits, pool->units, &ds);
1918
1919 /*
1920 * If this prefix is not in use, we're happy with it
1921 */
1922 test_iapref = NULL;
1923 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iapref, pool->leases,
1924 &tmp, sizeof(tmp), MDL) == 0) {
1925 break;
1926 }
1927 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iapref, MDL);
1928
1929 /*
1930 * Otherwise, we create a new input, adding the prefix
1931 */
1932 memset(&new_ds, 0, sizeof(new_ds));
1933 new_ds.len = ds.len + sizeof(tmp);
1934 if (!buffer_allocate(&new_ds.buffer, new_ds.len, MDL)) {
1935 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1936 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
1937 }
1938 new_ds.data = new_ds.buffer->data;
1939 memcpy(new_ds.buffer->data, ds.data, ds.len);
1940 memcpy(new_ds.buffer->data + ds.len, &tmp, sizeof(tmp));
1941 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1942 data_string_copy(&ds, &new_ds, MDL);
1943 data_string_forget(&new_ds, MDL);
1944 }
1945
1946 data_string_forget(&ds, MDL);
1947
1948 /*
1949 * We're happy with the prefix, create an IAPREFIX
1950 * to hold it.
1951 */
1952 iapref = NULL;
1953 result = iasubopt_allocate(&iapref, MDL);
1954 if (result != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1955 return result;
1956 }
1957 iapref->plen = (u_int8_t)pool->units;
1958 memcpy(&iapref->addr, &tmp, sizeof(iapref->addr));
1959
1960 /*
1961 * Add the prefix to the pool (note state is free, not active?!).
1962 */
1963 result = add_lease6(pool, iapref, soft_lifetime_end_time);
1964 if (result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
1965 iasubopt_reference(pref, iapref, MDL);
1966 }
1967 iasubopt_dereference(&iapref, MDL);
1968 return result;
1969}
1970
1971/*
1972 * Determine if a prefix is present in a pool or not.
1973 */
1974isc_boolean_t
1975prefix6_exists(const struct ipv6_pool *pool,
1976 const struct in6_addr *pref, u_int8_t plen) {
1977 struct iasubopt *test_iapref;
1978
1979 if ((int)plen != pool->units)
1980 return ISC_FALSE;
1981
1982 test_iapref = NULL;
1983 if (iasubopt_hash_lookup(&test_iapref, pool->leases,
1984 (void *)pref, sizeof(*pref), MDL)) {
1985 iasubopt_dereference(&test_iapref, MDL);
1986 return ISC_TRUE;
1987 } else {
1988 return ISC_FALSE;
1989 }
1990}
1991
1992/*
1993 * Mark an IPv6 address/prefix as unavailable from a pool.
1994 *
1995 * This is used for host entries and the addresses of the server itself.
1996 */
1997static isc_result_t
1998mark_lease_unavailable(struct ipv6_pool *pool, const struct in6_addr *addr) {
1999 struct iasubopt *dummy_iasubopt;
2000 isc_result_t result;
2001
2002 dummy_iasubopt = NULL;
2003 result = iasubopt_allocate(&dummy_iasubopt, MDL);
2004 if (result == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2005 dummy_iasubopt->addr = *addr;
2006 iasubopt_hash_add(pool->leases, &dummy_iasubopt->addr,
2007 sizeof(*addr), dummy_iasubopt, MDL);
2008 }
2009 return result;
2010}
2011
2012/*
2013 * Add a pool.
2014 */
2015isc_result_t
2016add_ipv6_pool(struct ipv6_pool *pool) {
2017 struct ipv6_pool **new_pools;
2018
2019 new_pools = dmalloc(sizeof(struct ipv6_pool *) * (num_pools+1), MDL);
2020 if (new_pools == NULL) {
2021 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
2022 }
2023
2024 if (num_pools > 0) {
2025 memcpy(new_pools, pools,
2026 sizeof(struct ipv6_pool *) * num_pools);
2027 dfree(pools, MDL);
2028 }
2029 pools = new_pools;
2030
2031 pools[num_pools] = NULL;
2032 ipv6_pool_reference(&pools[num_pools], pool, MDL);
2033 num_pools++;
2034 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2035}
2036
2037static void
2038cleanup_old_expired(struct ipv6_pool *pool) {
2039 struct iasubopt *tmp;
2040 struct ia_xx *ia;
2041 struct ia_xx *ia_active;
2042 unsigned char *tmpd;
2043 time_t timeout;
2044
2045 while (pool->num_inactive > 0) {
2046 tmp = (struct iasubopt *)
2047 isc_heap_element(pool->inactive_timeouts, 1);
2048 if (tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time != 0) {
2049 timeout = tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time;
2050 timeout += EXPIRED_IPV6_CLEANUP_TIME;
2051 } else {
2052 timeout = tmp->soft_lifetime_end_time;
2053 }
2054 if (cur_time < timeout) {
2055 break;
2056 }
2057
2058 isc_heap_delete(pool->inactive_timeouts, tmp->inactive_index);
2059 pool->num_inactive--;
2060
2061 if (tmp->ia != NULL) {
2062 /*
2063 * Check to see if this IA is in an active list,
2064 * but has no remaining resources. If so, remove it
2065 * from the active list.
2066 */
2067 ia = NULL;
2068 ia_reference(&ia, tmp->ia, MDL);
2069 ia_remove_iasubopt(ia, tmp, MDL);
2070 ia_active = NULL;
2071 tmpd = (unsigned char *)ia->iaid_duid.data;
2072 if ((ia->ia_type == D6O_IA_NA) &&
2073 (ia->num_iasubopt <= 0) &&
2074 (ia_hash_lookup(&ia_active, ia_na_active, tmpd,
2075 ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL) == 0) &&
2076 (ia_active == ia)) {
2077 ia_hash_delete(ia_na_active, tmpd,
2078 ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL);
2079 }
2080 if ((ia->ia_type == D6O_IA_TA) &&
2081 (ia->num_iasubopt <= 0) &&
2082 (ia_hash_lookup(&ia_active, ia_ta_active, tmpd,
2083 ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL) == 0) &&
2084 (ia_active == ia)) {
2085 ia_hash_delete(ia_ta_active, tmpd,
2086 ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL);
2087 }
2088 if ((ia->ia_type == D6O_IA_PD) &&
2089 (ia->num_iasubopt <= 0) &&
2090 (ia_hash_lookup(&ia_active, ia_pd_active, tmpd,
2091 ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL) == 0) &&
2092 (ia_active == ia)) {
2093 ia_hash_delete(ia_pd_active, tmpd,
2094 ia->iaid_duid.len, MDL);
2095 }
2096 ia_dereference(&ia, MDL);
2097 }
2098 iasubopt_dereference(&tmp, MDL);
2099 }
2100}
2101
2102static void
2103lease_timeout_support(void *vpool) {
2104 struct ipv6_pool *pool;
2105 struct iasubopt *lease;
2106
2107 pool = (struct ipv6_pool *)vpool;
2108 for (;;) {
2109 /*
2110 * Get the next lease scheduled to expire.
2111 *
2112 * Note that if there are no leases in the pool,
2113 * expire_lease6() will return ISC_R_SUCCESS with
2114 * a NULL lease.
2115 *
2116 * expire_lease6() will call move_lease_to_inactive() which
2117 * calls ddns_removals() do we want that on the standard
2118 * expiration timer or a special 'depref' timer? Original
2119 * query from DH, moved here by SAR.
2120 */
2121 lease = NULL;
2122 if (expire_lease6(&lease, pool, cur_time) != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2123 break;
2124 }
2125 if (lease == NULL) {
2126 break;
2127 }
2128
2129 write_ia(lease->ia);
2130
2131 iasubopt_dereference(&lease, MDL);
2132 }
2133
2134 /*
2135 * If appropriate commit and rotate the lease file
2136 * As commit_leases_timed() checks to see if we've done any writes
2137 * we don't bother tracking if this function called write _ia
2138 */
2139 (void) commit_leases_timed();
2140
2141 /*
2142 * Do some cleanup of our expired leases.
2143 */
2144 cleanup_old_expired(pool);
2145
2146 /*
2147 * Schedule next round of expirations.
2148 */
2149 schedule_lease_timeout(pool);
2150}
2151
2152/*
2153 * For a given pool, add a timer that will remove the next
2154 * lease to expire.
2155 */
2156void
2157schedule_lease_timeout(struct ipv6_pool *pool) {
2158 struct iasubopt *tmp;
2159 time_t timeout;
2160 time_t next_timeout;
2161 struct timeval tv;
2162
2163 next_timeout = MAX_TIME;
2164
2165 if (pool->num_active > 0) {
2166 tmp = (struct iasubopt *)
2167 isc_heap_element(pool->active_timeouts, 1);
2168 if (tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time < next_timeout) {
2169 next_timeout = tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time + 1;
2170 }
2171 }
2172
2173 if (pool->num_inactive > 0) {
2174 tmp = (struct iasubopt *)
2175 isc_heap_element(pool->inactive_timeouts, 1);
2176 if (tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time != 0) {
2177 timeout = tmp->hard_lifetime_end_time;
2178 timeout += EXPIRED_IPV6_CLEANUP_TIME;
2179 } else {
2180 timeout = tmp->soft_lifetime_end_time + 1;
2181 }
2182 if (timeout < next_timeout) {
2183 next_timeout = timeout;
2184 }
2185 }
2186
2187 if (next_timeout < MAX_TIME) {
2188 tv.tv_sec = next_timeout;
2189 tv.tv_usec = 0;
2190 add_timeout(&tv, lease_timeout_support, pool,
2191 (tvref_t)ipv6_pool_reference,
2192 (tvunref_t)ipv6_pool_dereference);
2193 }
2194}
2195
2196/*
2197 * Schedule timeouts across all pools.
2198 */
2199void
2200schedule_all_ipv6_lease_timeouts(void) {
2201 int i;
2202
2203 for (i=0; i<num_pools; i++) {
2204 schedule_lease_timeout(pools[i]);
2205 }
2206}
2207
2208/*
2209 * Given an address and the length of the network mask, return
2210 * only the network portion.
2211 *
2212 * Examples:
2213 *
2214 * "fe80::216:6fff:fe49:7d9b", length 64 = "fe80::"
2215 * "2001:888:1936:2:216:6fff:fe49:7d9b", length 48 = "2001:888:1936::"
2216 */
2217static void
2218ipv6_network_portion(struct in6_addr *result,
2219 const struct in6_addr *addr, int bits) {
2220 unsigned char *addrp;
2221 int mask_bits;
2222 int bytes;
2223 int extra_bits;
2224 int i;
2225
2226 static const unsigned char bitmasks[] = {
2227 0x00, 0xFE, 0xFC, 0xF8,
2228 0xF0, 0xE0, 0xC0, 0x80,
2229 };
2230
2231 /*
2232 * Sanity check our bits. ;)
2233 */
2234 if ((bits < 0) || (bits > 128)) {
2235 log_fatal("ipv6_network_portion: bits %d not between 0 and 128",
2236 bits);
2237 }
2238
2239 /*
2240 * Copy our address portion.
2241 */
2242 *result = *addr;
2243 addrp = ((unsigned char *)result) + 15;
2244
2245 /*
2246 * Zero out masked portion.
2247 */
2248 mask_bits = 128 - bits;
2249 bytes = mask_bits / 8;
2250 extra_bits = mask_bits % 8;
2251
2252 for (i=0; i<bytes; i++) {
2253 *addrp = 0;
2254 addrp--;
2255 }
2256 if (extra_bits) {
2257 *addrp &= bitmasks[extra_bits];
2258 }
2259}
2260
2261/*
2262 * Determine if the given address/prefix is in the pool.
2263 */
2264isc_boolean_t
2265ipv6_in_pool(const struct in6_addr *addr, const struct ipv6_pool *pool) {
2266 struct in6_addr tmp;
2267
2268 ipv6_network_portion(&tmp, addr, pool->bits);
2269 if (memcmp(&tmp, &pool->start_addr, sizeof(tmp)) == 0) {
2270 return ISC_TRUE;
2271 } else {
2272 return ISC_FALSE;
2273 }
2274}
2275
2276/*
2277 * Find the pool that contains the given address.
2278 *
2279 * - pool must be a pointer to a (struct ipv6_pool *) pointer previously
2280 * initialized to NULL
2281 */
2282isc_result_t
2283find_ipv6_pool(struct ipv6_pool **pool, u_int16_t type,
2284 const struct in6_addr *addr) {
2285 int i;
2286
2287 if (pool == NULL) {
2288 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", MDL);
2289 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2290 }
2291 if (*pool != NULL) {
2292 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", MDL);
2293 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2294 }
2295
2296 for (i=0; i<num_pools; i++) {
2297 if (pools[i]->pool_type != type)
2298 continue;
2299 if (ipv6_in_pool(addr, pools[i])) {
2300 ipv6_pool_reference(pool, pools[i], MDL);
2301 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2302 }
2303 }
2304 return ISC_R_NOTFOUND;
2305}
2306
2307/*
2308 * Helper function for the various functions that act across all
2309 * pools.
2310 */
2311static isc_result_t
2312change_leases(struct ia_xx *ia,
2313 isc_result_t (*change_func)(struct ipv6_pool *,
2314 struct iasubopt *)) {
2315 isc_result_t retval;
2316 isc_result_t renew_retval;
2317 struct ipv6_pool *pool;
2318 struct in6_addr *addr;
2319 int i;
2320
2321 retval = ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2322 for (i=0; i<ia->num_iasubopt; i++) {
2323 pool = NULL;
2324 addr = &ia->iasubopt[i]->addr;
2325 if (find_ipv6_pool(&pool, ia->ia_type,
2326 addr) == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2327 renew_retval = change_func(pool, ia->iasubopt[i]);
2328 if (renew_retval != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2329 retval = renew_retval;
2330 }
2331 }
2332 /* XXXsk: should we warn if we don't find a pool? */
2333 }
2334 return retval;
2335}
2336
2337/*
2338 * Renew all leases in an IA from all pools.
2339 *
2340 * The new lifetime should be in the soft_lifetime_end_time
2341 * and will be moved to hard_lifetime_end_time by renew_lease6.
2342 */
2343isc_result_t
2344renew_leases(struct ia_xx *ia) {
2345 return change_leases(ia, renew_lease6);
2346}
2347
2348/*
2349 * Release all leases in an IA from all pools.
2350 */
2351isc_result_t
2352release_leases(struct ia_xx *ia) {
2353 return change_leases(ia, release_lease6);
2354}
2355
2356/*
2357 * Decline all leases in an IA from all pools.
2358 */
2359isc_result_t
2360decline_leases(struct ia_xx *ia) {
2361 return change_leases(ia, decline_lease6);
2362}
2363
2364#ifdef DHCPv6
2365/*
2366 * Helper function to output leases.
2367 */
2368static int write_error;
2369
2370static isc_result_t
2371write_ia_leases(const void *name, unsigned len, void *value) {
2372 struct ia_xx *ia = (struct ia_xx *)value;
2373
2374 if (!write_error) {
2375 if (!write_ia(ia)) {
2376 write_error = 1;
2377 }
2378 }
2379 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2380}
2381
2382/*
2383 * Write all DHCPv6 information.
2384 */
2385int
2386write_leases6(void) {
2387 int nas, tas, pds;
2388
2389 write_error = 0;
2390 write_server_duid();
2391 nas = ia_hash_foreach(ia_na_active, write_ia_leases);
2392 if (write_error) {
2393 return 0;
2394 }
2395 tas = ia_hash_foreach(ia_ta_active, write_ia_leases);
2396 if (write_error) {
2397 return 0;
2398 }
2399 pds = ia_hash_foreach(ia_pd_active, write_ia_leases);
2400 if (write_error) {
2401 return 0;
2402 }
2403
2404 log_info("Wrote %d NA, %d TA, %d PD leases to lease file.",
2405 nas, tas, pds);
2406 return 1;
2407}
2408#endif /* DHCPv6 */
2409
2410static isc_result_t
2411mark_hosts_unavailable_support(const void *name, unsigned len, void *value) {
2412 struct host_decl *h;
2413 struct data_string fixed_addr;
2414 struct in6_addr addr;
2415 struct ipv6_pool *p;
2416
2417 h = (struct host_decl *)value;
2418
2419 /*
2420 * If the host has no address, we don't need to mark anything.
2421 */
2422 if (h->fixed_addr == NULL) {
2423 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2424 }
2425
2426 /*
2427 * Evaluate the fixed address.
2428 */
2429 memset(&fixed_addr, 0, sizeof(fixed_addr));
2430 if (!evaluate_option_cache(&fixed_addr, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL,
2431 &global_scope, h->fixed_addr, MDL)) {
2432 log_error("mark_hosts_unavailable: "
2433 "error evaluating host address.");
2434 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2435 }
2436 if (fixed_addr.len != 16) {
2437 log_error("mark_hosts_unavailable: "
2438 "host address is not 128 bits.");
2439 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2440 }
2441 memcpy(&addr, fixed_addr.data, 16);
2442 data_string_forget(&fixed_addr, MDL);
2443
2444 /*
2445 * Find the pool holding this host, and mark the address.
2446 * (I suppose it is arguably valid to have a host that does not
2447 * sit in any pool.)
2448 */
2449 p = NULL;
2450 if (find_ipv6_pool(&p, D6O_IA_NA, &addr) == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2451 mark_lease_unavailable(p, &addr);
2452 ipv6_pool_dereference(&p, MDL);
2453 }
2454 if (find_ipv6_pool(&p, D6O_IA_TA, &addr) == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2455 mark_lease_unavailable(p, &addr);
2456 ipv6_pool_dereference(&p, MDL);
2457 }
2458
2459 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2460}
2461
2462void
2463mark_hosts_unavailable(void) {
2464 hash_foreach(host_name_hash, mark_hosts_unavailable_support);
2465}
2466
2467static isc_result_t
2468mark_phosts_unavailable_support(const void *name, unsigned len, void *value) {
2469 struct host_decl *h;
2470 struct iaddrcidrnetlist *l;
2471 struct in6_addr pref;
2472 struct ipv6_pool *p;
2473
2474 h = (struct host_decl *)value;
2475
2476 /*
2477 * If the host has no prefix, we don't need to mark anything.
2478 */
2479 if (h->fixed_prefix == NULL) {
2480 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2481 }
2482
2483 /*
2484 * Get the fixed prefixes.
2485 */
2486 for (l = h->fixed_prefix; l != NULL; l = l->next) {
2487 if (l->cidrnet.lo_addr.len != 16) {
2488 continue;
2489 }
2490 memcpy(&pref, l->cidrnet.lo_addr.iabuf, 16);
2491
2492 /*
2493 * Find the pool holding this host, and mark the prefix.
2494 * (I suppose it is arguably valid to have a host that does not
2495 * sit in any pool.)
2496 */
2497 p = NULL;
2498 if (find_ipv6_pool(&p, D6O_IA_PD, &pref) != ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2499 continue;
2500 }
2501 if (l->cidrnet.bits != p->units) {
2502 ipv6_pool_dereference(&p, MDL);
2503 continue;
2504 }
2505 mark_lease_unavailable(p, &pref);
2506 ipv6_pool_dereference(&p, MDL);
2507 }
2508
2509 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2510}
2511
2512void
2513mark_phosts_unavailable(void) {
2514 hash_foreach(host_name_hash, mark_phosts_unavailable_support);
2515}
2516
2517void
2518mark_interfaces_unavailable(void) {
2519 struct interface_info *ip;
2520 int i;
2521 struct ipv6_pool *p;
2522
2523 ip = interfaces;
2524 while (ip != NULL) {
2525 for (i=0; i<ip->v6address_count; i++) {
2526 p = NULL;
2527 if (find_ipv6_pool(&p, D6O_IA_NA, &ip->v6addresses[i])
2528 == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2529 mark_lease_unavailable(p,
2530 &ip->v6addresses[i]);
2531 ipv6_pool_dereference(&p, MDL);
2532 }
2533 if (find_ipv6_pool(&p, D6O_IA_TA, &ip->v6addresses[i])
2534 == ISC_R_SUCCESS) {
2535 mark_lease_unavailable(p,
2536 &ip->v6addresses[i]);
2537 ipv6_pool_dereference(&p, MDL);
2538 }
2539 }
2540 ip = ip->next;
2541 }
2542}
2543
2544/*!
2545 * \brief Create a new IPv6 pond structure.
2546 *
2547 * Allocate space for a new ipv6_pond structure and return a reference
2548 * to it, includes setting the reference count to 1.
2549 *
2550 * \param pond = space for returning a referenced pointer to the pond.
2551 * This must point to a space that has been initialzied
2552 * to NULL by the caller.
2553 *
2554 * \return
2555 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = The pond was successfully created, pond points to it.
2556 * DHCP_R_INVALIDARG = One of the arugments was invalid, pond has not been
2557 * modified
2558 * ISC_R_NOMEMORY = The system wasn't able to allocate memory, pond has
2559 * not been modified.
2560 */
2561isc_result_t
2562ipv6_pond_allocate(struct ipv6_pond **pond, const char *file, int line) {
2563 struct ipv6_pond *tmp;
2564
2565 if (pond == NULL) {
2566 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
2567 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2568 }
2569 if (*pond != NULL) {
2570 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
2571 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2572 }
2573
2574 tmp = dmalloc(sizeof(*tmp), file, line);
2575 if (tmp == NULL) {
2576 return ISC_R_NOMEMORY;
2577 }
2578
2579 tmp->refcnt = 1;
2580
2581 *pond = tmp;
2582 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2583}
2584
2585/*!
2586 *
2587 * \brief reference an IPv6 pond structure.
2588 *
2589 * This function genreates a reference to an ipv6_pond structure
2590 * and increments the reference count on the structure.
2591 *
2592 * \param[out] pond = space for returning a referenced pointer to the pond.
2593 * This must point to a space that has been initialzied
2594 * to NULL by the caller.
2595 * \param[in] src = A pointer to the pond to reference. This must not be
2596 * NULL.
2597 *
2598 * \return
2599 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = The pond was successfully referenced, pond now points
2600 * to src.
2601 * DHCP_R_INVALIDARG = One of the arugments was invalid, pond has not been
2602 * modified.
2603 */
2604isc_result_t
2605ipv6_pond_reference(struct ipv6_pond **pond, struct ipv6_pond *src,
2606 const char *file, int line) {
2607 if (pond == NULL) {
2608 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
2609 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2610 }
2611 if (*pond != NULL) {
2612 log_error("%s(%d): non-NULL pointer", file, line);
2613 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2614 }
2615 if (src == NULL) {
2616 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer reference", file, line);
2617 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2618 }
2619 *pond = src;
2620 src->refcnt++;
2621 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2622}
2623
2624/*!
2625 *
2626 * \brief de-reference an IPv6 pond structure.
2627 *
2628 * This function decrements the reference count in an ipv6_pond structure.
2629 * If this was the last reference then the memory for the structure is
2630 * freed.
2631 *
2632 * \param[in] pond = A pointer to the pointer to the pond that should be
2633 * de-referenced. On success the pointer to the pond
2634 * is cleared. It must not be NULL and must not point
2635 * to NULL.
2636 *
2637 * \return
2638 * ISC_R_SUCCESS = The pond was successfully de-referenced, pond now points
2639 * to NULL
2640 * DHCP_R_INVALIDARG = One of the arugments was invalid, pond has not been
2641 * modified.
2642 */
2643
2644isc_result_t
2645ipv6_pond_dereference(struct ipv6_pond **pond, const char *file, int line) {
2646 struct ipv6_pond *tmp;
2647
2648 if ((pond == NULL) || (*pond == NULL)) {
2649 log_error("%s(%d): NULL pointer", file, line);
2650 return DHCP_R_INVALIDARG;
2651 }
2652
2653 tmp = *pond;
2654 *pond = NULL;
2655
2656 tmp->refcnt--;
2657 if (tmp->refcnt < 0) {
2658 log_error("%s(%d): negative refcnt", file, line);
2659 tmp->refcnt = 0;
2660 }
2661 if (tmp->refcnt == 0) {
2662 dfree(tmp, file, line);
2663 }
2664
2665 return ISC_R_SUCCESS;
2666}
2667
2668#ifdef EUI_64
2669/*
2670 * Enables/disables EUI-64 address assignment for a pond
2671 *
2672 * Excecutes statements down to the pond's scope and sets the pond's
2673 * use_eui_64 flag accordingly. In addition it iterates over the
2674 * pond's pools ensuring they are all /64. Anything else is deemed
2675 * invalid for EUI-64. It returns the number of invalid pools
2676 * detected. This is done post-parsing as use-eui-64 can be set
2677 * down to the pool scope and we can't reliably do it until the
2678 * entire configuration has been parsed.
2679 */
2680int
2681set_eui_64(struct ipv6_pond *pond) {
2682 int invalid_cnt = 0;
2683 struct option_state* options = NULL;
2684 struct option_cache *oc = NULL;
2685 option_state_allocate(&options, MDL);
2686 execute_statements_in_scope(NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, options,
2687 &global_scope, pond->group, NULL, NULL);
2688
2689 pond->use_eui_64 =
2690 ((oc = lookup_option(&server_universe, options, SV_USE_EUI_64))
2691 &&
2692 (evaluate_boolean_option_cache (NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL,
2693 options, NULL, &global_scope,
2694 oc, MDL)));
2695 if (pond->use_eui_64) {
2696 // Check all pools are valid
