2697 int i = 0;
2698 struct ipv6_pool* p;
2699 while((p = pond->ipv6_pools[i++]) != NULL) {
2700 if (p->bits != 64) {
2701 log_error("Pool %s/%d cannot use EUI-64,"
2702 " prefix must 64",
2703 pin6_addr(&p->start_addr), p->bits);
2704 invalid_cnt++;
2705 } else {
2706 log_debug("Pool: %s/%d - will use EUI-64",
2707 pin6_addr(&p->start_addr), p->bits);
2708 }
2709 }
2710 }
2711
2712 /* Don't need the options anymore. */
2713 option_state_dereference(&options, MDL);
2714 return (invalid_cnt);
2715}
2716#endif
2717
2718/*
2719 * Emits a log for each pond that has been flagged as being a "jumbo range"
2720 * A pond is considered a "jumbo range" when the total number of elements
2721 * exceeds the maximum value of POND_TRACK_MAX (currently maximum value
2722 * that can be stored by ipv6_pond.num_total). Since we disable threshold
2723 * logging for jumbo ranges, we need to report this to the user. This
2724 * function allows us to report jumbo ponds after config parsing, so the
2725 * logs can be seen both on the console (-T) and the log facility (i.e syslog).
2726 *
2727 * Note, threshold logging is done at the pond level, so we need emit a list
2728 * of the addresses ranges of the pools in the pond affected.
2729 */
2730void
2731report_jumbo_ranges() {
2732 struct shared_network* s;
2733 char log_buf[1084];
2734#ifdef EUI_64
2735 int invalid_cnt = 0;
2736#endif
2737
2738 /* Loop thru all the networks looking for jumbo range ponds */
2739 for (s = shared_networks; s; s = s -> next) {
2740 struct ipv6_pond* pond = s->ipv6_pond;
2741 while (pond) {
2742#ifdef EUI_64
2743 /* while we're here, set the pond's use_eui_64 flag */
2744 invalid_cnt += set_eui_64(pond);
2745#endif
2746 /* if its a jumbo and has pools(sanity check) */
2747 if (pond->jumbo_range == 1 && (pond->ipv6_pools)) {
2748 struct ipv6_pool* pool;
2749 char *bufptr = log_buf;
2750 size_t space_left = sizeof(log_buf) - 1;
2751 int i = 0;
2752 int used = 0;
2753
2754 /* Build list containing the start-address/CIDR
2755 * of each pool */
2756 *bufptr = '\0';
2757 while ((pool = pond->ipv6_pools[i++]) &&
2758 (space_left > (INET6_ADDRSTRLEN + 6))) {
2759 /* more than one so add a comma */
2760 if (i > 1) {
2761 *bufptr++ = ',';
2762 *bufptr++ = ' ';
2763 *bufptr = '\0';
2764 space_left -= 2;
2765 }
2766
2767 /* add the address */
2768 inet_ntop(AF_INET6, &pool->start_addr,
2769 bufptr, INET6_ADDRSTRLEN);
2770
2771 used = strlen(bufptr);
2772 bufptr += used;
2773 space_left -= used;
2774
2775 /* add the CIDR */
2776 sprintf (bufptr, "/%d",pool->bits);
2777 used = strlen(bufptr);
2778 bufptr += used;
2779 space_left -= used;
2780 *bufptr = '\0';
2781 }
2782
2783 log_info("Threshold logging disabled for shared"
2784 " subnet of ranges: %s", log_buf);
2785 }
2786 pond = pond->next;
2787 }
2788
2789 }
2790
2791#ifdef EUI_64
2792 if (invalid_cnt) {
2793 log_fatal ("%d pool(s) are invalid for EUI-64 use",
2794 invalid_cnt);
2795 }
2796#endif
2797}
2798
2799
2800/*
2801 * \brief Tests that 16-bit hardware type is less than 256
2802 *
2803 * XXX: DHCPv6 gives a 16-bit field for the htype. DHCPv4 gives an
2804 * 8-bit field. To change the semantics of the generic 'hardware'
2805 * structure, we would have to adjust many DHCPv4 sources (from
2806 * interface to DHCPv4 lease code), and we would have to update the
2807 * 'hardware' config directive (probably being reverse compatible and
2808 * providing a new upgrade/replacement primitive). This is a little
2809 * too much to change for now. Hopefully we will revisit this before
2810 * hardware types exceeding 8 bits are assigned.
2811 *
2812 * Uses a static variable to limit log occurence to once per startup
2813 *
2814 * \param htype hardware type value to test
2815 *
2816 * \return returns 0 if the value is too large
2817 *
2818*/
2819static int
2820htype_bounds_check(uint16_t htype) {
2821 static int log_once = 0;
2822
2823 if (htype & 0xFF00) {
2824 if (!log_once) {
2825 log_error("Attention: At least one client advertises a "
2826 "hardware type of %d, which exceeds the software "
2827 "limitation of 255.", htype);
2828 log_once = 1;
2829 }
2830
2831 return(0);
2832 }
2833
2834 return(1);
2835}
2836
2837/*!
2838 * \brief Look for hosts by MAC address if it's available
2839 *
2840 * Checks the inbound packet against host declarations which specified:
2841 *
2842 * "hardware ethernet <MAC>;"
2843 *
2844 * For directly connected clients, the function will use the MAC address
2845 * contained in packet:haddr if it's populated. \TODO - While the logic is in
2846 * place for this search, the socket layer does not yet populate packet:haddr,
2847 * this is to be done under rt41523.
2848 *
2849 * For relayed clients, the function will use the MAC address from the
2850 * client-linklayer-address option if it has been supplied by the relay
2851 * directly connected to the client.
2852 *
2853 * \param hp[out] - pointer to storage for the host delcaration if found
2854 * \param packet - received packet
2855 * \param opt_state - option state to search
2856 * \param file - source file
2857 * \param line - line number
2858 *
2859 * \return non-zero if a matching host was found, zero otherwise
2860*/
2861static int
2862find_hosts_by_haddr6(struct host_decl **hp,
2863 struct packet *packet,
2864 struct option_state *opt_state,
2865 const char *file, int line) {
2866 int found = 0;
2867 int htype;
2868 int hlen;
2869
2870 /* For directly connected clients, use packet:haddr if populated */
2871 if (packet->dhcpv6_container_packet == NULL) {
2872 if (packet->haddr) {
2873 htype = packet->haddr->hbuf[0];
2874 hlen = packet->haddr->hlen - 1,
2875 log_debug("find_hosts_by_haddr6: using packet->haddr,"
2876 " type: %d, len: %d", htype, hlen);
2877 found = find_hosts_by_haddr (hp, htype,
2878 &packet->haddr->hbuf[1],
2879 hlen, MDL);
2880 }
2881 } else {
2882 /* The first container packet is the from the relay directly
2883 * connected to the client. Per RFC 6939, that is only relay
2884 * that may supply the client linklayer address option. */
2885 struct packet *relay_packet = packet->dhcpv6_container_packet;
2886 struct option_state *relay_state = relay_packet->options;
2887 struct data_string rel_addr;
2888 struct option_cache *oc;
2889
2890 /* Look for the option in the first relay packet */
2891 oc = lookup_option(&dhcpv6_universe, relay_state,
2892 D6O_CLIENT_LINKLAYER_ADDR);
2893 if (!oc) {
2894 /* Not there, so bail */
2895 return (0);
2896 }
2897
2898 /* The option is present, fetch the address data */
2899 memset(&rel_addr, 0, sizeof(rel_addr));
2900 if (!evaluate_option_cache(&rel_addr, relay_packet, NULL, NULL,
2901 relay_state, NULL, &global_scope,
2902 oc, MDL)) {
2903 log_error("find_hosts_by_add6:"
2904 "Error evaluating option cache");
2905 return (0);
2906 }
2907
2908 /* The relay address data should be:
2909 * byte 0 - 1 = hardware type
2910 * bytes 2 - hlen = hardware address
2911 * where hlen ( hardware address len) is option data len - 2 */
2912 hlen = rel_addr.len - 2;
2913 if (hlen > 0 && hlen <= HARDWARE_ADDR_LEN) {
2914 htype = getUShort(rel_addr.data);
2915 if (htype_bounds_check(htype)) {
2916 /* Looks valid, let's search with it */
2917 log_debug("find_hosts_by_haddr6:"
2918 "using relayed haddr"
2919 " type: %d, len: %d", htype, hlen);
2920 found = find_hosts_by_haddr (hp, htype,
2921 &rel_addr.data[2],
2922 hlen, MDL);
2923 }
2924 }
2925
2926 data_string_forget(&rel_addr, MDL);
2927 }
2928
2929 return (found);
2930}
2931
2932/*
2933 * find_host_by_duid_chaddr() synthesizes a DHCPv4-like 'hardware'
2934 * parameter from a DHCPv6 supplied DUID (client-identifier option),
2935 * and may seek to use client or relay supplied hardware addresses.
2936 */
2937static int
2938find_hosts_by_duid_chaddr(struct host_decl **host,
2939 const struct data_string *client_id) {
2940 int htype, hlen;
2941 const unsigned char *chaddr;
2942
2943 /*
2944 * The DUID-LL and DUID-LLT must have a 2-byte DUID type and 2-byte
2945 * htype.
2946 */
2947 if (client_id->len < 4)
2948 return 0;
2949
2950 /*
2951 * The third and fourth octets of the DUID-LL and DUID-LLT
2952 * is the hardware type, but in 16 bits.
2953 */
2954 htype = getUShort(client_id->data + 2);
2955 hlen = 0;
2956 chaddr = NULL;
2957
2958 /* The first two octets of the DUID identify the type. */
2959 switch(getUShort(client_id->data)) {
2960 case DUID_LLT:
2961 if (client_id->len > 8) {
2962 hlen = client_id->len - 8;
2963 chaddr = client_id->data + 8;
2964 }
2965 break;
2966
2967 case DUID_LL:
2968 /*
2969 * Note that client_id->len must be greater than or equal
2970 * to four to get to this point in the function.
2971 */
2972 hlen = client_id->len - 4;
2973 chaddr = client_id->data + 4;
2974 break;
2975
2976 default:
2977 break;
2978 }
2979
2980 if ((hlen == 0) || (hlen > HARDWARE_ADDR_LEN) ||
2981 !htype_bounds_check(htype)) {
2982 return (0);
2983 }
2984
2985 return find_hosts_by_haddr(host, htype, chaddr, hlen, MDL);
2986}
2987
2988/*
2989 * \brief Finds a host record that matches the packet, if any
2990 *
2991 * This function centralizes the logic for matching v6 client
2992 * packets to host declarations. We check in the following order
2993 * for matches with:
2994 *
2995 * 1. client_id if specified
2996 * 2. MAC address when explicitly available
2997 * 3. packet option
2998 * 4. synthesized hardware address - this is done last as some
2999 * synthesis methods are not consided to be reliable
3000 *
3001 * \param[out] host - pointer to storage for the located host
3002 * \param packet - inbound client packet
3003 * \param client_id - client identifier (if one)
3004 * \param file - source file
3005 * \param line - source file line number
3006 * \return non-zero if a host is found, zero otherwise
3007*/
3008int
3009find_hosts6(struct host_decl** host, struct packet* packet,
3010 const struct data_string* client_id, char* file, int line) {
3011 return (find_hosts_by_uid(host, client_id->data, client_id->len, MDL)
3012 || find_hosts_by_haddr6(host, packet, packet->options, MDL)
3013 || find_hosts_by_option(host, packet, packet->options, MDL)
3014 || find_hosts_by_duid_chaddr(host, client_id));
3015}
